description: Core electrical concepts: voltage, current, resistance, and power

topics.title: Electric Charge

definition.text: Electric charge is a fundamental property of matter that causes it to experience a force in an electromagnetic field. Electrons carry negative charge (-1.6 Ã— 10â»Â¹â¹ coulombs) while protons carry positive charge. The unit of charge is the Coulomb (C), where 1 Coulomb = 6.24 Ã— 10Â¹â¸ electrons.

keyFormulas.name: Coulomb's Law
keyFormulas.formula: F = k Ã— (qâ‚ Ã— qâ‚‚) / rÂ²
keyFormulas.meaning: Force between two charges: k = 8.99 Ã— 10â¹ NÂ·mÂ²/CÂ²

examples.question: How many electrons flow through a wire if 2A current flows for 5 seconds?

steps.result: Q = I Ã— t = 2A Ã— 5s = 10 C

realWorldApplications.title: Static Electricity
realWorldApplications.description: Why you get shocked touching a doorknob in winter

realWorldApplications.title: Lightning
realWorldApplications.description: Massive charge buildup between clouds and ground

realWorldApplications.title: Photocopiers
realWorldApplications.description: Use electrostatic charge to transfer toner to paper

codeExample.python:
# Calculate charge from current and time
def calculate_charge(current_amps, time_seconds):
    """Q = I Ã— t"""
    return current_amps * time_seconds

# Calculate number of electrons
def electrons_count(charge_coulombs):
    electron_charge = 1.6e-19  # Coulombs
    return charge_coulombs / electron_charge

# Example: 2A for 5 seconds
charge = calculate_charge(2, 5)  # 10 Coulombs
electrons = electrons_count(charge)  # 6.25e19 electrons

tips: Remember: Like charges repel, opposite charges attract
1 Coulomb is a HUGE amount of charge - about 6.24 Ã— 10Â¹â¸ electrons
Static electricity is just separated charges, not moving electrons

topics.title: Voltage (EMF)

definition.text: Voltage, also called electromotive force (EMF) or potential difference, is the electrical pressure that pushes electrons through a circuit. It's measured in Volts (V). Think of voltage like water pressure - it provides the 'push' to move electrons from negative to positive terminal.

examples.question: A battery does 12 Joules of work to move 4 Coulombs of charge. What is the voltage?

realWorldApplications.title: Household Power
realWorldApplications.description: 120V (US) or 230V (Europe) AC for home appliances

realWorldApplications.title: Car Battery
realWorldApplications.description: 12V DC to power vehicle electronics and starting

realWorldApplications.title: USB Charging
realWorldApplications.description: 5V DC standard for smartphones and devices

codeExample.python:
# Common voltage levels
voltage_sources = {
    'AA Battery': 1.5,
    'USB': 5.0,
    'Car Battery': 12.0,
    'US Outlet (RMS)': 120.0,
    'EU Outlet (RMS)': 230.0,
    'Tesla Supercharger': 480.0
}

# Ohm's Law: Calculate voltage
def voltage_from_current_resistance(I, R):
    return I * R

# Example: 2A through 5Î©
V = voltage_from_current_resistance(2, 5)  # 10V

tips: Voltage is always measured BETWEEN two points (potential difference)
Higher voltage means more 'electrical pressure' to push current
Be careful: voltages above 50V can be dangerous to touch!

topics.title: Electric Current

definition.text: Electric current is the flow of electric charge through a conductor, measured in Amperes (A). One ampere equals one coulomb of charge passing a point per second. Current flows from positive to negative (conventional current) but electrons actually move from negative to positive.

examples.question: What current flows through a 10Î© resistor connected to a 5V source?

realWorldApplications.title: Phone Charger
realWorldApplications.description: Typically 1-3A for fast charging

realWorldApplications.title: Light Bulb
realWorldApplications.description: LED bulb uses about 0.1A, incandescent uses 0.5A

realWorldApplications.title: Electric Stove
realWorldApplications.description: Can draw 30-50A for high-power heating elements

codeExample.python:
# Current calculations
def current_from_voltage_resistance(V, R):
    """Ohm's Law: I = V/R"""
    return V / R

def current_from_charge_time(Q, t):
    """I = Q/t"""
    return Q / t

# Common current ratings
currents = {
    'LED': 0.02,      # 20mA
    'USB 2.0': 0.5,   # 500mA
    'USB 3.0': 0.9,   # 900mA
    'Fast Charge': 3.0,  # 3A
    'Wall Outlet': 15.0  # 15A typical circuit
}

tips: DC current flows in one direction; AC current alternates direction
Current is the same everywhere in a series circuit
Milliamps (mA) = Amps Ã— 1000 - common for small electronics

topics.title: Resistance

definition.text: Resistance is the opposition to current flow in a material, measured in Ohms (Î©). It depends on the material's resistivity, length, and cross-sectional area. Conductors have low resistance, insulators have high resistance. Resistors are components designed to provide specific resistance values.

keyFormulas.name: Resistance of a Wire
keyFormulas.meaning: R = resistivity Ã— length / cross-sectional area

examples.question: A 12V battery pushes 3A through a resistor. What is its resistance?

realWorldApplications.title: Resistor Color Codes
realWorldApplications.description: Bands on resistors indicate their value

realWorldApplications.title: Light Dimmer
realWorldApplications.description: Variable resistor to control brightness

realWorldApplications.title: Heating Elements
realWorldApplications.description: Nichrome wire with specific resistance for toasters, heaters

tips: Use Ohm's Law triangle: V on top, I and R on bottom
Resistors in series ADD: Rtotal = R1 + R2
Resistors in parallel: 1/Rtotal = 1/R1 + 1/R2

topics.title: Ohm's Law

definition.text: Ohm's Law is the fundamental relationship between voltage, current, and resistance: V = I Ã— R. It states that current through a conductor is directly proportional to voltage and inversely proportional to resistance. This law is the foundation of all circuit analysis.

examples.question: An LED requires 20mA at 2V. What resistor is needed with a 5V supply?

realWorldApplications.title: LED Current Limiting
realWorldApplications.description: Calculate resistors to protect LEDs

realWorldApplications.title: Fuse Selection
realWorldApplications.description: Determine current flow to size fuses correctly

realWorldApplications.title: Wire Sizing
realWorldApplications.description: Calculate voltage drop in long wire runs

tips: Draw the Ohm's Law triangle: V on top, IÃ—R on bottom
Cover what you want to find - the remaining shows the formula
Always check units: V in Volts, I in Amps, R in Ohms

topics.title: Electrical Power

definition.text: Electrical power is the rate at which electrical energy is transferred, measured in Watts (W). Power can be calculated using P = V Ã— I, or by combining with Ohm's Law: P = IÂ²R or P = VÂ²/R. Power bills are based on energy consumption in kilowatt-hours (kWh).

examples.question: A 100W bulb operates at 120V. What current does it draw?

realWorldApplications.title: Electricity Bill
realWorldApplications.description: Charged by kWh - 1000W for 1 hour = 1 kWh

realWorldApplications.title: Heat Generation
realWorldApplications.description: P = IÂ²R shows why wires heat up with high current

realWorldApplications.title: Appliance Ratings
realWorldApplications.description: Microwave (1000W), Hair dryer (1500W), AC (2000W)

tips: Power formulas: P=VI, P=IÂ²R, P=VÂ²/R - know all three!
1 kWh = 1000W Ã— 1 hour = 3.6 megajoules
Heat dissipation = power rating - match resistor wattage!

topics.title: Energy & Work

definition.text: Electrical energy is the capacity to do work, measured in Joules (J) or kilowatt-hours (kWh). Energy = Power Ã— Time. One kWh is the energy used by a 1000W device running for one hour. Efficiency measures how much input energy is converted to useful output.

keyFormulas.name: Energy in Joules
keyFormulas.formula: E = P Ã— t = V Ã— I Ã— t
keyFormulas.latex: E = P \cdot t = V \cdot I \cdot t

examples.question: A 2000W air conditioner runs 8 hours/day for 30 days. What's the electricity cost at $0.15/kWh?

realWorldApplications.title: Energy Star Ratings
realWorldApplications.description: Appliance efficiency comparisons

realWorldApplications.title: Solar Panel Sizing
realWorldApplications.description: Calculate daily kWh needs for system design

realWorldApplications.title: Battery Capacity
realWorldApplications.description: Watt-hours (Wh) determine runtime

codeExample.python:
# Energy and efficiency calculator
def monthly_cost(power_watts, hours_per_day, days, rate_per_kwh):
    daily_kwh = (power_watts / 1000) * hours_per_day
    monthly_kwh = daily_kwh * days
    return monthly_kwh * rate_per_kwh

def efficiency(power_out, power_in):
    return (power_out / power_in) * 100

def battery_runtime_hours(battery_wh, device_watts):
    return battery_wh / device_watts

# Examples
ac_cost = monthly_cost(2000, 8, 30, 0.15)  # $72
led_efficiency = efficiency(9, 10)  # 90% efficient
laptop_runtime = battery_runtime_hours(50, 45)  # ~1.1 hours

tips: 1 kWh = 3,600,000 Joules = 3.6 MJ
LED bulbs: ~90% efficient. Incandescent: ~5% (rest is heat!)
Always match battery Wh capacity to device W consumption

topics.title: Conductors & Insulators

definition.text: Conductors are materials that allow easy flow of electric current (low resistance), like copper and aluminum. Insulators resist current flow (high resistance), like rubber and plastic. Semiconductors are in between and form the basis of modern electronics.

keyFormulas.name: Wire Resistance
keyFormulas.meaning: Ï = resistivity, L = length, A = cross-sectional area

examples.question: Why is copper used for house wiring instead of aluminum?
examples.finalAnswer: Copper has lower resistance and better connections, but aluminum is used for long-distance power lines due to weight/cost

realWorldApplications.title: Wire Gauge Selection
realWorldApplications.description: Thicker wire = lower resistance for high current

realWorldApplications.title: Insulation Ratings
realWorldApplications.description: PVC, rubber, Teflon for different voltages/temperatures

realWorldApplications.title: Heat Sinks
realWorldApplications.description: Aluminum conducts heat away from electronics

codeExample.python:
# Material resistivity (Î©Â·m at 20Â°C)
materials = {
    'silver': 1.59e-8,
    'copper': 1.68e-8,
    'gold': 2.44e-8,
    'aluminum': 2.65e-8,
    'tungsten': 5.6e-8,
    'nichrome': 1.10e-6,  # heating elements
    'silicon': 2.3e3,      # semiconductor
    'glass': 1e10,         # insulator
    'rubber': 1e13         # excellent insulator
}

def wire_resistance(resistivity, length_m, area_m2):
    return resistivity * length_m / area_m2

# AWG to area conversion
def awg_to_area_mm2(awg):
    return 0.012668 * (92 ** ((36 - awg) / 19.5))

tips: Good conductors: Silver > Copper > Gold > Aluminum
Wire gauge: Lower number = thicker wire = lower resistance
Semiconductors can be 'doped' to change conductivity
